title: What does the 'S' in SOLID stand for?
explanation: The 'S' stands for Single Responsibility Principle. This principle states that a class should have only one reason to change.

title: The Single Responsibility Principle (SRP) states a class should have only one:
explanation: SRP is defined by the idea that a class should have only one reason to change, meaning it has only one job or responsibility.

title: Which design pattern is often used to adhere to the Open/Closed Principle (OCP)?
explanation: The Strategy pattern allows you to define a family of algorithms, encapsulate each one, and make them interchangeable, fulfilling the 'open for extension' part of OCP.

title: Open for extension
description: closed for modification"" defines which SOLID principle?
options: Single Responsibility Principle|Liskov Substitution Principle|Open/Closed Principle|Interface Segregation Principle
explanation: The Open/Closed Principle (OCP) states that software entities (classes, modules, functions, etc.) should be open for extension, but closed for modification.

title: Violating the Liskov Substitution Principle (LSP) often leads to:
options: God Objects|Unnecessary type checking ('instanceof')|Tight Coupling|Increased boilerplate code
explanation: Violating LSP often forces the client code to check the actual type of the object (using 'instanceof') to see if it can safely call a method, which is a code smell.

title: The Liskov Substitution Principle (LSP) ensures that subtypes are _________ for their base types.
explanation: LSP dictates that objects of a superclass should be replaceable with objects of its subclasses without breaking the application.

title: What is the primary benefit of the Interface Segregation Principle (ISP)?
options: Reduces the number of classes|Prevents large 'fat' interfaces|Enforces one method per interface|Promotes loose coupling between layers
explanation: ISP aims to keep interfaces small and client-specific, avoiding 'fat' interfaces that force implementors to depend on methods they don't use.

title: A client should not be forced to depend on methods it does not use"" is the core idea of:
options: Open/Closed Principle|Dependency Inversion Principle|Interface Segregation Principle|Single Responsibility Principle
explanation: This is the definition of the Interface Segregation Principle (ISP), promoting smaller, role-specific interfaces.

title: In Dependency Inversion Principle (DIP)
explanation: DIP states that high-level modules should not depend on low-level modules. Both should depend on abstractions (interfaces or abstract classes).

title: Which SOLID principle promotes the use of Dependency Injection (DI)?
explanation: Dependency Injection is a common technique used to implement the Dependency Inversion Principle (DIP) by injecting dependencies as abstractions.

title: A class that handles both data validation and database persistence violates which principle?
options: Open/Closed Principle|Liskov Substitution Principle|Single Responsibility Principle|Dependency Inversion Principle
explanation: The class has two distinct 'reasons to change': one for validation logic and one for persistence logic, violating SRP.

title: The relationship where high-level modules depend on abstractions and low-level modules also depend on those abstractions is defined by:
options: Open/Closed Principle|Liskov Substitution Principle|Interface Segregation Principle|Dependency Inversion Principle
explanation: DIP reverses the traditional dependency flow: both high-level (business logic) and low-level (implementation details) depend on an abstraction.

title: The Open/Closed Principle is typically achieved through:
options: Inheritance and Polymorphism|Private methods and Final classes|Static methods and Utility classes|Direct class instantiation
explanation: By programming to an interface or abstract class (polymorphism), you can swap in new implementations (extension) without changing the existing client code (closed for modification).

title: Which principle states that subclasses should be able to seamlessly replace their base classes?
explanation: LSP is all about type substitutability, ensuring that a subtype can be used wherever its supertype is expected.

title: Which principle is most closely associated with reducing the impact of changes in one part of the system on another (Decoupling)?
explanation: DIP is the primary principle for decoupling, ensuring that high-level logic is shielded from changes in low-level implementation details through abstraction.
